page.title: 01 LIFE ON THE MARSHES.
page.content: All lands around Crowle were owned by the Abbots of Selby, from Norman times to the reign of Henry VIII. In those days, much of the present land around Crowle was either Forest land or Marshland. Indeed, out of all the land in our area, only{Cottage Farm}is recorded in the Domesday Book of 1086. {Rainsbutt Farm}was covered with forest and the rest of the land was marshland and very often under water. The marshes and forests supplied the people with much that they needed. Rushes and hemp provided raw materials for baskets, wattle fencing, seats and ropes. The KIng's deer was often poached in the forest while the flooded marshes provided fish-roach, perch, bream, eels and even salmon. There was also plenty of wildfowl to hunt: duck, geese, heron, curlew and snipe.
